thread.title: Two new venture capital funds in L.A.: One for gaming. One for business software
thread.title_full: Two new venture capital funds in L.A.: One for gaming. One for business software

author: Paresh Dave
title: Two new venture capital funds in L.A.: One for gaming. One for business software
text:
Two new venture capital funds in L.A.: One for gaming. One for business software Xsolla Capital partners Xsolla Capital Xsolla Capital has raised $30 million to invest in video game makers. From left, its managing partner Brett Brown, partner Alex Agapitov and partner Dmitry Bourkovsky. Xsolla Capital has raised $30 million to invest in video game makers. From left, its managing partner Brett Brown, partner Alex Agapitov and partner Dmitry Bourkovsky. (Xsolla Capital) 
Start-up development program Amplify.LA recorded nearly $370 million in seed investment to Los Angeles companies last year, according to the Los Angeles Business Journal . About 250 investors disbursed the cash across 180 deals, according to the firmâ€™s tally. 
Tinder acquired Los Angeles video-sharing app company Wheel for an undisclosed amount, according to Variety . In case you missed it 
Snap sets IPO targets : $3.7-billion windfall and $22-billion valuation. 
How much money Snap's existing shareholders could reap in the IPO. 
Snap is headed toward Los Angeles' biggest IPO ever. How come local venture capitalists missed out? 
Snap poached a top Instagram executive in 2014. But it ended in an expensive resignation . 
San Francisco loves tech and fancy coffee. So of course it has barista robots . Coming up 
Splash Ventures, a Los Angeles mentorship program for Israeli start-ups, is scheduled to hold a showcase of eight such companies on Wednesday. Presenters include a company building a virtual assistant to help with math homework and a company trying to build a simple gardening system for marijuana.
